reasoning: The critique targets Section 3.5’s discussion of intertheoretic comparisons/normalization and argues that operationalizing it in governance would induce metric-gaming and volatility. That is only moderately central to the essay’s core thesis (“no easy eutopia”/fussiness of most moral views), because Section 3.5 is an add-on about moral uncertainty and decision procedures rather than a load-bearing premise for eutopian fragility or fussiness. As an attack on 3.5’s practical import, it has some force: Goodhart-style dynamics and denominator manipulation are real risks when metrics become institutionalized, and the paper largely treats normalization as an intellectual choice rather than a sociopolitical equilibrium. However, it doesn’t much refute the underlying philosophical claims in 3.5 (that normalization choices can flip recommendations; that some methods make unbounded views loom larger), and it’s somewhat speculative/empirical in its causal story (funders, dashboards, volatility) without support. The argument is clear and focused with little fluff; most claims are plausible as risks rather than established facts, so correctness is fairly high but not near-1.
title: Treating intertheoretic normalization as technical invites metric gaming and funding instability
